title: LAPD Crime Data Analysis
description: An end-to-end data warehouse involving data cleaning, modelling, and PowerBI visualization.
process: In this project, I built an end-to-end data pipeline using the Medallion (Bronze-Silver-Gold) architecture to transform raw LAPD crime data into actionable insights via Power BI dashboards. After initializing the environment with SQL Server, I ingested raw CSV data into the Bronze layer for traceability. In the Silver layer, I cleaned and standardized the data using SQL, then normalized it into a Snowflake schema to improve data integrity and reduce redundancy. At the Gold layer, I denormalized the data into a Star schema optimized for analytics and built semantic Gold Views. These views powered a fully interactive Power BI dashboard featuring crime heatmaps, yearly trend analysis, and victim demographic insights. The structured approach ensured scalable data processing, robust modeling, and user-friendly visual reporting.

title: COVID-19 Insights: Muntinlupa City 2020
description: Data analysis of COVID-19 dataset focused in Muntinlupa City on 2020.
process: In this project, I extracted, cleaned, and analyzed over 1M rows of COVID-19 data using Microsoft Excel. I extracted the required data using MySQL and transformed the raw, extracted data using MS Excel. After cleaning, I developed an interactive Tableau dashboard to present key metrics such as recovery rate and incorporated cards, graphs, filters, and charts to visualize trends and patterns.

title: Coffee Sales Dashboard
description: Data analysis of a coffee sales dataset considering factors such as sales, order type, and order date.
process: The coffee sales dataset was given in a star schema via an Excel file with multiple sheets. I denormalized the dataset first using XLOOKUP and INDEX-MATCH functions and cleaned and transformed the data using IFs and other advanced functions. Afterward, I developed an Excel-based dashboard to visualize the trends and integrated slicers and filters to support user exploration.
